posts.post_text: February 6, 2017 at 5:01 PM#9Here are the pieces to know - you should be able to figure it out from there.Conditional ExpressionsAddvar keywordTo jump to a specific macro line: [color=#66FF33]Macro[/color] 1.x.y (x = macro number or "name" ; y = macro line)- If you're on v3.2, looping will work fine like that. If you're on v3.1, you'd need to specify the entire range of lines getting looped, or break those into a separate macro that can loop from the last line to the first line.

posts.author: redfresnel
posts.post_text: February 6, 2017 at 6:08 PM#10And i did!Here's what i came up with:SetVar $from = (Take selection from effect...)SetVar $to = (...to effect?)SetVar $counter = $from[$counter <= $to] Store Effect 1.$counter.*AddVar $counter = 1[$counter <= $to] Macro 1."Take selection from/to".4

posts.author: Duplicate Ryan Kanarek
posts.post_text: February 6, 2017 at 6:14 PM#11Looks pretty good! A couple suggestions:- Don't really need $counter = $from - you can just use $from as the counter.- Might want to add /overwrite (/o) on the end of your Store line, so that you don't get a popup- Don't really need the conditional on the Store line. You're always going to want it to run the first time, right? After that, it will only get run again based on the second conditional anyway.
